Class CoreTimeLine

java.lang.Object
userInterface.backEnd.CoreTimeLine
public class CoreTimeLine extends Object
Visual timeline model for a single core used by the back‑end UI renderer.

A CoreTimeLine collects TaskExecution segments (execution, waiting, context switch, migration, error markers) and knows how to paint itself and associated per‑segment resource usage rectangles onto a supplied Graphics context. The horizontal axis is time (scaled by the parent ScheduleResult's base unit) and two stacked lanes are drawn: the core status lane and a parallel task lane (labelled "Task").

Integrated original inline comments (Chinese):

  • "時間軸起始位置" – the point o is the origin (start position) of the time axis.
  • "畫時間軸" / "畫時間軸刻度" – loops draw the timeline line(s) and tick marks.
  • Status handling (E / X, MIGRATION, CONTEXTSWITCH, WAIT, WRONG, EXECUTION) determines fill colors, half‑height vs full‑height bars, and label formatting (taskID, jobID, times with fractional portions).
Colors for tasks and resources are selected from a predefined HSB palette and inverted (via reverseColor(Color)) for contrasting text to maximize readability inside narrow execution rectangles. Time labels are drawn only when fractional (two decimals) and optionally throttled depending on parent scale to avoid clutter.
Author:
ShiuJia

  • Constructor Details

    • CoreTimeLine

      public CoreTimeLine()
      Creates an empty core timeline with no parent or executions. The origin and identifier must be set later (typically by using the other constructor) before drawing; adding executions without a parent base unit will yield undefined placement.

    • CoreTimeLine

      public CoreTimeLine(ScheduleResult sr, int i, String id)
      Constructs a core timeline bound to a ScheduleResult parent and logically identifies it with the provided string ID.
      Parameters:
      sr - the owning scheduling result that supplies scaling (base unit), final time, and vertical spacing parameters
      i - zero‑based vertical index of this core; used to compute the y offset from the common origin via parent.getTaskGap()
      id - textual core identifier (parsed to integer and stored in ID)
      Throws:
      NumberFormatException - if id cannot be parsed as an integer

  • Method Details

    • addExecution

      public void addExecution(TaskExecution te)
      Appends a TaskExecution segment (execution, wait, context switch, migration, error marker) to this timeline. The segment will later be rendered in drawItself(Graphics) and resources shown via drawResources(TimeLineResult).
      Parameters:
      te - the execution segment to add (order determines draw layering)

    • drawItself

      public void drawItself(Graphics g)
      Renders the entire core timeline onto the provided graphics context.

      Drawing steps:

      1. Draws auxiliary task lane ("Task") and primary time axis, including arrowheads and tick marks, respecting parent scaling and label density (scale heuristic).
      2. Iterates each TaskExecution and paints a colored rectangle whose style (height, color, half vs full bar) depends on its Definition.CoreStatus (MIGRATION=blue half bar, CONTEXTSWITCH=light gray half bar, WAIT=filled full bar, EXECUTION=outlined bar, WRONG=red X).
      3. Overlays task/job identifiers within bars when width permits; short bars show truncated identifiers.
      4. Labels fractional start/end times when their first decimal digit is non-zero (reduces clutter).
      Resource usage rectangles are not drawn here; see drawResources(TimeLineResult) and reDrawResources(TimeLineResult, Graphics).
      Parameters:
      g - the graphics context to draw into (coordinates relative to UI component)

    • drawResources

      public void drawResources(TimeLineResult rv)
      Adds visual resource usage panels for each EXECUTION segment into the provided timeline result container and positions them (without drawing their contents). Invoked prior to a paint pass so that the UI components are laid out.
      Parameters:
      rv - the container accumulating resource panels for later rendering

    • reDrawResources

      public void reDrawResources(TimeLineResult rv, Graphics g)
      Repositions and redraws resource usage rectangles for EXECUTION segments directly onto the supplied graphics context, also writing textual labels (resource set ID, instance number, and total amount) when width allows. Typically called during repaint to refresh visual alignment after scale or size changes.
      Parameters:
      rv - the timeline result container holding existing resource panels
      g - the graphics context used for immediate painting

    • reverseColor

      public Color reverseColor(Color color)
      Produces a contrasting color by inverting the RGB channels of the given color (simple 255 - component inversion) to ensure readable text over filled rectangles.
      Parameters:
      color - the original color
      Returns:
      the inverted (reverse) color
